00002  * \file DMS.hpp

00010 #if !defined(GEOGRAPHICLIB_DMS_HPP)
00011 #define GEOGRAPHICLIB_DMS_HPP "$Id: DMS.hpp 6785 2010-01-05 22:15:42Z karney $"
00012 
00013 #include "GeographicLib/Constants.hpp"
00014 #include <sstream>
00015 
00016 namespace GeographicLib {
00017 
00018   /**
00019    * \brief Convert between degrees and %DMS representation.
00020    *
00021    * Parse a string representing degree, minutes, and seconds and return the
00022    * angle in degrees and format an angle in degrees as degree, minutes, and
00023    * seconds.
00024    **********************************************************************/
00025   class DMS {
00026   private:
00027     typedef Math::real real;
00028     static int lookup(const std::string& s, char c) throw() {
00029       std::string::size_type r = s.find(toupper(c));
00030       return r == std::string::npos ? -1 : int(r);
00031     }
00032     template<typename T> static std::string str(T x) {
00033       std::ostringstream s; s << x; return s.str();
00034     }
00035     static const std::string hemispheres;
00036     static const std::string signs;
00037     static const std::string digits;
00038     static const std::string dmsindicators;
00039     static const std::string components[3];
00040     DMS();                      // Disable constructor
00041 
00042   public:
00043 
00044     /**
00045      * Indicator for presence of hemisphere indicator (N/S/E/W) on latitudes
00046      * and longitudes.  AZIMUTH is used in Encode to indicate output in [000,
00047      * 360) with no letter indicator.
00048      **********************************************************************/
00049     enum flag { NONE = 0, LATITUDE = 1, LONGITUDE = 2, AZIMUTH = 3 };
00050 
00051     /**
00052      * Indicator for trailing units on an angle.
00053      **********************************************************************/
00054     enum component { DEGREE = 0, MINUTE = 1, SECOND = 2 };
00055 
00056     /**
00057      * Read a string \e dms in DMS format and return the resulting angle in
00058      * degrees.  Degrees, minutes, and seconds are indicated by the letters d,
00059      * ', ", and these components may only be given in this order.  Any (but
00060      * not all) components may be omitted.  The last component indicator may be
00061      * omitted and is assumed to be tbe next smallest unit (thus 33d10 is
00062      * interpreted as 33d10').  The final component may be a decimal fraction
00063      * but the non-final components must be integers.  The integer parts of the
00064      * minutes and seconds components must be less than 60.  A single leading
00065      * sign is permitted.  A hemisphere designator (N, E, W, S) may be added to
00066      * tbe beginning or end of the string.  The result is multiplied by the
00067      * implied signed of the hemisphere designator (negative for S and W).  In
00068      * addition \e flag is used to indicate whether such a designator was found
00069      * and whether it implies that the angle is a latitude (N or S) or
00070      * longitude (E or W).  Throws an error on a malformed string.  No check is
00071      * performed on the range of the result.
00072      **********************************************************************/
00073     static Math::real Decode(const std::string& dms, flag& ind);
00074 
00075     /**
00076      * Convert real degrees \e d, minutes \e m, and seconds \e s, to degrees.
00077      * This does not propagate the sign on \e d to the other components, so
00078      * -3d20' would need to be represented as - DMS::Decode(3.0, 20.0) or
00079      * DMS::Decode(-3.0, -20.0).
00080      **********************************************************************/
00081     static Math::real Decode(real d, real m = 0, real s = 0) throw()
00082     { return d + (m + s/real(60))/real(60); }
00083 
00084     /**
00085      * Convert two strings \e dmsa and \e dmsb to a latitude, \e lat, and
00086      * longitude, \e lon.  By default, the \e lat (resp., \e lon) is assigned
00087      * to the results of decoding \e dmsa (resp., \e dmsb).  However this is
00088      * overridden if either \e dmsa or \e dmsb contain a latitude or longitude
00089      * hemisphere designator (N, S, E, W).  Throws an error if the decoded
00090      * numbers are out of the ranges [-90<sup>o</sup>, 90<sup>o</sup>] for
00091      * latitude and [-180<sup>o</sup>, 360<sup>o</sup>] for longitude and, in
00092      * which case \e lat and \e lon are unchanged.  Finally the longitude is
00093      * reduced to the range [-180<sup>o</sup>, 180<sup>o</sup>).
00094      **********************************************************************/
00095     static void DecodeLatLon(const std::string& dmsa, const std::string& dmsb,
00096                              real& lat, real& lon);
00097 
00098     /**
00099      * Convert \e degree into a DMS string.  \e trailing indicates the least
00100      * significant component of the string (and this component is given as a
00101      * decimal number if necessary).  \e prec indicates the number of digits
00102      * after the decimal point for the trailing component.  \e flag indicates
00103      * additional formating as follows
00104      * - flag == NONE, signed result no leading zeros on degrees except in the
00105      *   units place, e.g., -8d03'.
00106      * - flag == LATITUDE, trailing N or S hemisphere designator, no sign, pad
00107      *   degress to 2 digits, e.g., 08d03'S.
00108      * - flag == LONGITUDE, trailing E or W hemisphere designator, no sign, pad
00109      *   degress to 3 digits, e.g., 008d03'W.
00110      * - flag == AZIMUTH, convert to the range [0, 360<sup>o</sup>), no sign,
00111      *   pad degrees to 3 digits, , e.g., 351d57'.
00112      * .
00113      * The integer parts of the minutes and seconds components are always given
00114      * with 2 digits.
00115      **********************************************************************/
00116     static std::string Encode(real degree, component trailing, unsigned prec,
00117                               flag ind = NONE);
00118 
00119     /**
00120      * Convert \e degree into a DMS string selecting the trailing component
00121      * based on \e prec.  \e prec indicates the precision relative to 1 degree,
00122      * e.g., \e prec = 3 gives a result accurate to 0.1' and \e prec = 4 gives
00123      * a result accurate to 1".
00124      **********************************************************************/
00125     static std::string Encode(real degree, unsigned prec, flag ind = NONE) {
00126       return Encode(degree,
00127                     prec < 2 ? DEGREE : (prec < 4 ? MINUTE : SECOND),
00128                     prec < 2 ? prec : (prec < 4 ? prec - 2 : prec - 4),
00129                     ind);
00130     }
00131 
00132     /**
00133      * Split angle, \e ang, into degrees, \e d, and minutes \e m.
00134      **********************************************************************/
00135     static void Encode(real ang, real& d, real& m) throw() {
00136       d = int(ang); m = 60 * (ang - d);
00137     }
00138 
00139     /**
00140      * Split angle, \e ang, into degrees, \e d, minutes, \e m, and seconds \e
00141      * s.
00142      **********************************************************************/
00143     static void Encode(real ang, real& d, real& m, real& s) throw() {
00144       d = int(ang); ang = 60 * (ang - d);
00145       m = int(ang); s = 60 * (ang - m);
00146     }
00147 
00148   };
00149 
00150 } // namespace GeographicLib
00151 
00152 #endif
